claim: If the football player with the highest overall rating in this database had been born one week later than 1987-06-24, he would have represented a different national team.
extra_info: football player who has the highest overall rating refers to MAX(overall_rating);
reasoning: This is a counterfactual claim ('If the player had been born one week later... he would have represented a different national team'). The database records what actually happened, not what would have happened under hypothetical scenarios like a different birth date. Counterfactual claims cannot be verified from factual data.

content.text:
This claim is a counterfactual — it describes a hypothetical "what if" scenario: "If the player had been born one week later, he would have represented a different national team." This is speculating about what *would have happened* under different circumstances, not what actually happened.

According to my workflow rules, counterfactual claims should always be classified as NOT ENOUGH INFO, because the database only records what actually happened, not what would have happened under hypothetical changes.

```json
{"label": "NOT ENOUGH INFO", "reasoning": "This is a counterfactual claim ('If the player had been born one week later... he would have represented a different national team'). The database records what actually happened, not what would have happened under hypothetical scenarios like a different birth date. Counterfactual claims cannot be verified from factual data."}
```
